title: TONY HETHERINGTON: I invested £70,000 in wine... but now it has gone missing
text:
B.J. writes: I have been dealing with the Bordeaux Wine Company since 2011. Until this year, everything ran well, though the wines that were sold for me showed a loss. My last transaction was a year ago, since when I have had great difficulty in making contact with them to get my wine portfolio released to the bonded warehouse where I have an account.

Since you first contacted me, you will have seen my report last Sunday about the disgraceful state of affairs at BWC – a business which has not only kept its real name secret, but has also hidden from its investors the name of the man who pulls the strings.

On paper, the business is run by Boington Anthony Grant, but the true boss is Freddie Achom. Not that it makes much difference. Both have criminal records for fraud. Both were banned for years from acting as company directors.

But even while breaking the law year after year, Achom has raised his profile to the point where he appears on lists of Britain’s most successful and influential black business personalities.

On paper, the business is run by Boington Anthony Grant, but the true boss is Freddie Achom. Not that it makes much difference. Both have criminal records for fraud...

Last week, I published a picture of him chatting with then Prime Minister David Cameron in Downing Street. And today, here he is hobnobbing with Royalty at a reception at St James’s Palace. I ask again – does nobody vet the guests at these events?

Leaving aside the wines you sold at a loss, you invested over £70,000 with BWC. But despite all your requests, wine worth only about £10,000 has been released by BWC to the bonded warehouse. The rest is unaccounted for. I asked BWC to explain. It did not. I also asked BWC for the full legal name of the business. Again, it failed to comment.

And this is important, because it has traded under a variety of names, all without identifying the person, persons, or company using those names. This is illegal.

Misleadingly, anyone who checked with Companies House would have found that there really was a Bordeaux Wine Company Limited. It was owned by its sole director Arlene King. She told me: ‘I was an employee of Bordeaux Wine Company who was asked to become a director in January 2005, although it was only ever in a nominal sense as I remained an employee and had no operational control.’

She added that shortly afterwards, her employers – who she fails to name – ‘transferred all of the assets of the Bordeaux Wine Company to the partnership called BWC Management and Consulting Partners and that became the operative entity for all of their wine dealings.’ Who were those partners? King does not say.

Bordeaux Wine Company Limited was compulsorily struck off by officials at Companies House last February. But for years it filed accounts and was listed as an unblemished business.

Last week, I published a picture of him chatting with then Prime Minister David Cameron in Downing Street. And today, here he is hobnobbing with Royalty at a reception at St James’s Palace. I ask again – does nobody vet the guests at these events?

Customers of the mysterious business that called itself simply ‘BWC’, and sold wine as an investment, and had Arlene King as manager, might well have checked with Companies House and seen that all was well, not knowing that the business they poured their money into was secretly run by Freddie Achom and Boington Grant.

King is now director of yet another wine company, Our Sommelier Limited, which she set up while she was still employed as general manager of BWC.

But her role at BWC is not the first time she has been working for a company where the real boss was hiding in the background.

From 2005 to 2010, King was company secretary of Australian Portfolio Wines UK Limited and for three of those years she was a director as well. After a Government investigation, the High Court ordered in 2015 that the company be shut down. Liquidators found that the company had ‘lent’ £1.2 million to its real boss Freddie Achom. They counted themselves lucky to recover £700,000 from him.

But Achom had been banned as a company director after the collapse of an even earlier wine investment business. So in 2016, he appeared at Southwark Crown Court where he pleaded guilty to breaching that ban.

The court heard that from 2004 to 2013, no major decision at Australian Portfolio Wines was made without his say-so. He was the secret boss, hiding behind Arlene King and others. For this, he was given a suspended prison sentence and ordered to pay a cash penalty of £945,000 or face five years in jail.

So where does all this leave you? At some point BWC became the trading name of a company called Management & Consulting Partners Unlimited, registered to Achom’s business partner Boington Grant. And last Monday, that company transferred its registered office to the address of a firm of insolvency experts.

This is very unlikely to be good news for you. Does your wine exist? BWC will not say. If it exists, is it in your name? BWC will not say. Arlene King, who distances herself from BWC, told me: ‘I had no real authority whatsoever to make any meaningful decisions.’

She added: ‘I abhor some of the practices of this trade, which is why my company is totally transparent in the way it is run’, which is not something that could be said about BWC. This cries out for an Insolvency Service investigation – and soon.
